t: Proverbs 31
The Words of Lemuel
The*p words of King Lemuel, the oracle which his mother taught him:
What,*pn O my son? And*ln what, O son of my womb? And*ln what, O son of my vows?
Do*ln not give your strength to women, Or*ln your ways to that which destroys kings.
It*ln is not for kings, O Lemuel, It*ln is not for kings to drink wine, Or*ln for rulers to desire strong drink,
For*ln they will drink and forget what is decreed, And*ln pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
Give*ln strong drink to him who is perishing, And*ln wine to him whose life is bitter.
Let*ln him drink and forget his poverty And*ln remember his trouble no more.
Open*ln your mouth for the mute, For*ln the rights of all the unfortunate.
Open*ln your mouth, judge righteously, And*ln defend the rights of the afflicted and needy.
Description of a Worthy Woman
An*pn excellent wife, who can find? For*ln her worth is far above jewels.
The*ln heart of her husband trusts in her, And*ln he will have no lack of gain.
She*ln does him good and not evil All*ln the days of her life.
She*ln looks for wool and flax And*ln works with her hands in delight.
She*ln is like merchant ships; She*ln brings her food from afar.
She*ln rises also while it is still night And*ln gives food to her household And*ln portions to her maidens.
She*ln considers a field and buys it; From*ln her earnings she plants a vineyard.
She*ln girds herself with strength And*ln makes her arms strong.
She*ln senses that her gain is good; Her*ln lamp does not go out at night.
She*ln stretches out her hands to the distaff, And*ln her hands grasp the spindle.
She*ln extends her hand to the poor, And*ln she stretches out her hands to the needy.
She*ln is not afraid of the snow for her household, For*ln all her household are clothed with scarlet.
She*ln makes coverings for herself; Her*ln clothing is fine linen and purple.
Her*ln husband is known in the gates, When*ln he sits among the elders of the land.
She*ln makes linen garments and sells them,*i And*ln supplies belts to the tradesmen.
Strength*ln and dignity are her clothing, And*ln she smiles at the future.
She*ln opens her mouth in wisdom, And*ln the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
She*ln looks well to the ways of her household, And*ln does not eat the bread of idleness.
Her*ln children rise up and bless her; Her*ln husband also,*i and he praises her, saying:*i
“Many*ln daughters have done nobly, But*ln you excel them all.”
Charm*ln is deceitful and beauty is vain, But*iln a woman who fears the Lord,*s she shall be praised.
Give*ln her the product of her hands, And*ln let her works praise her in the gates.
